4152.76.text: new ideas find fertile soil to push the envelope of their possibilities.

4162.33.text: You'll never know when you'll meet the dreaded ping of death,

4167.00.text: a special version of a normal request ping,

4169.89.text: which some idiot thought up to mess up unsuspecting hosts.

4179.13.text: telephone lines, wireless, or even transoceanic cable.

4183.09.text: They don't always take the fastest or shortest routes possible,

4186.52.text: but they will get there eventually.

4190.29.text: Maybe that's why it's sometimes called "The World Wide Wait."

4197.98.text: you can circumvent the globe five times over at the drop of a hat, literally.

4208.23.text: Near the end of our destination, we'll find another firewall.

4215.07.text: Depending upon your perspective as a data packet,

4218.42.text: the firewall could be a bastion of security or a dreaded adversary.

4223.73.text: It all depends on which side you're on and what your intentions are.

4228.53.text: The firewall is designed to let in only those packets that meet its criteria.

4234.99.text: This firewall is operating on ports 80 and 25.

4239.36.text: All attempts to enter through other ports are closed for business.

4257.66.text: Port 25 is used for mail packets,

4263.48.text: while port 80 is the entrance for packets from the Internet to the web server.

4270.72.text: Inside the firewall, packets are screened more thoroughly.

4275.08.text: Some packets make it easily through customs,

4277.97.text: while others look just a bit dubious.

4281.42.text: Now, the firewall officer is not easily fooled,

4284.06.text: such as when this ping of death packet tries to disguise itself as a normal ping packet.

4297.52.text: [Narrator] For those packets lucky enough to make it this far,

4305.73.text: It's just a line up on the interface to be taken up into the web server.

4312.13.text: Nowadays, a web server can run on many things,

4315.44.text: from a mainframe to a web cam to the computer on your desk.

4321.72.text: With the proper setup, you can find out if you have the makings

4324.87.text: for Chicken Cacciatore, or if you have to go shopping.

4328.39.text: Remember, this is the dawn of the Net.

4337.31.text: One by one, the packets are received,

4346.32.text: The information they contain, that is, your request for information,

4351.20.text: is sent on to the web server application.

4367.14.text: ready to be used again, and filled with your requested information,

4377.57.text: addressed, and sent out on its way back to you.

4383.34.text: Back past the firewall, routers, and on through to the Internet.

4404.18.text: ready to supply your web browser with the information you've requested.

4419.84.text: Pleased with their efforts, and trusting the better world,

4423.55.text: our trusty data packets ride off blissfully into the sunset of another day,

4430.25.text: knowing fully they have served their masters well.

4436.88.text: Now, isn't that a happy ending?

4442.56.text: [Malan] Okay, that's enough. We'll see you next week.
